content:
You're right, that looks like an error in instructions and I'll report it. The instruction works if you use the menu bar, not the hamburger menu. To follow its intent, if menu bar is not visible, click alt key and then click view>sort by>unthreaded. Here are more complete instructions if you have many folders:


This is the official (to my knowledge) documentation. Well worth the read https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/message-threading-thunderbird

Here is my own documentation on threading, duplicating the above, but it may help: You need to highlight each folder and click View>sort by>unthreaded. If this applies to just a few folders, just repeat the process as necessary. If you have many folders or plan to add many new folders, you may wish a different approach, below: 

More info:  To change default for *new* folders, In config editor, you can change default that applies to NEW folders you set up: mailnews.default_view_flags      0 =unthreaded    Config editor is available at Tools>settings>general and scroll to bottom right.    ------------ 	 To set many *existing* folders, follow these steps: This must be done on an account by account basis. - select table view  - the icon just to right of 'quick filter' button above message list pane - select a message folder and apply all desired attributes - View>sort by from menu bar (if not shown, click alt key) - click the icon at right side of column display in message list pane - select the entry near bottom 'Apply current view to...' - highlight 'folder and children' - move mouse left to see account name and move left again to display all account folders. Now CLICK. - a small menu will appear to confirm setting all folders within that account.  I did a simple (okay, crude) video at https://davidkirk.org/SettingDefaultFolderView.mp4   ALSO, for future installations of Thunderbird,  - create a simple text file with name of user.js with these lines:       // Set default threading to UNthreaded  ###   <== this line is optional, just for documentation      user_pref("mailnews.default_view_flags", 0); - install Thunderbird and exit prior to setting up accounts	  - copy the user.js file into the profile - now, when you start Thunderbird, unthreading will be the default. Problem solved.
creator: davidsk

content: Is this a POP account? If so, my guess is the popstate.dat file became corrupted, signaling to Thunderbird to download all mail. However, once done, the popstate.dat file should be ok. If the download repeats every time, it may be that Thunderbird is being prevented from updating that file.

creator: jpjrsf

content:
I will make an assumption, and you are not going to like it.

The read status of email is synced in an IMAP situation so we are seeing here one of two things. A complete failure of Thunderbird to link the read status of mails over a period of years to your providers web site. As I like many millions of others use Thunderbird with Gmail in an IMAP situation, I can confirm that while it can happen due to timeouts in connections it is rare, and only occurs for a short period. Like you mark a folder read and only half of them are marked before the connection ends for some reason like the power it off.

The second is you have something on your system that is causing issues (Not Thunderbird) although it could be an addon). So when you access your email on the gmail web site using your browser are these email marked as read as they should be or not? That is the first step is trying to determine what is happening.

content:
My suggestion is to exit thunderbird and do a BACKUP copy of profile: 

 c:\users\mary\appdata\roaming\thunderbird to external media to protect against a future problem. Then, should you have a crash or screwup or whatever, you could '

- reinstall thunderbird if necessary, - then exit thunderbird - then copy the backed up thunderbird folder to c:\users\mary\appdata\roaming to overwrite the existing thunderbirdfolder.

If you have a printer, I suggest printing this for future reference.

Also, if you do not like autoupdates, be sure to go to settings>general and change the setting to notify you, but not update automatically.

Regarding font color, that requires CSS customizations, which are not supported. I do not recommend doing that, as it increases the odds that something will go wrong in the setup and problems may surface.

content:
Purtroppo sei molto vago e stai mettendo assieme tante questioni differenti. Proviamo a risolvere una cosa alla volta.

(1) Per l'errore Il messaggio è stato inviato, ma non è stata salvata una copia... hai verificato che lo spazio sul server non sia esaurito?

(2) Thunderbird è solo un programma per leggere la posta. Quando chiedevo Chi è il fornitore dell'indirizzo email intendevo la società che gestisce fisicamente la tua casella di posta. Tipo Gmail, Libero Mail o anche il tuo hosting se hai un indirizzo di posta sul tuo dominio.

(3) Per sapere quale versione di Thunderbird stai usando vai Tasto menu > Aiuto > Informazioni su Thunderbird

content:
(1) Purtroppo non posso aiutarti. È una informazione che solo tu puoi recuperare. Tieni conto che quel messaggio significa che o che c'è un problema di spazio sul server, o che c'è un problema di spazio sul tuo disco locale, o che c'è un problema con i diritti di scrittura nella cartella di Thunderbird. Prova ad eseguire Thunderbird come Amministratore

  • Click destro sull'icona di Thunderbird
  • Esegui come amministratore

(2) Non sono necessari i tuoi indirizzi, ti chiedevo solo chi li gestisce. Da quel che vedo si tratta probabilmente dello stesso hosting che gestisce anche il dominio. Hai provato a chiedere loro di fornirti i parametri di configurazione aggiornati per le caselle di posta? Purtroppo anche qui io non posso aiutarti.

content: I may want to see screenshots of those folders to verify their content, but I will make an initial suggestion to see if it does what you want. click 'account setting' and scroll down left side to 'Local Folders' and click that. To the right, you will then see 'Local Directory' and a browse button. Click the browse button and then locate and select the folder on drive E. That may require restarting thunderbird. Let know results an we can go from there.
creator: davidsk

content: Yes, you may. And if you also have a local folders in the imapmail\<accountname> folder, that can also be deleted.

content:
The correct settings are outlook.office365.com for the incoming on port 995 (POP) or 993 (IMAP), SSL/TLS, OAuth2, email address. For the outgoing: smtp.office365.com, port 587, STARTTLS, OAuth2, email address.

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1417298#answer-1588949

content:
Help/Troubleshooting Info, Profile Folder, Open Folder, close TB, extract the zip file, which contains an .mbox file, into Mail/Local Folders, remove the .mbox extension, restart TB, find the folder under Local Folders in the Folder Pane.

Your picture actually shows the built-in Import option, not the one for the IET NG add-on, which can be accessed from the Local Folders context menu.

If you are planning to upload a folder with many messages to another gmail IMAP account, that is a bit more involved.
creator: sfhowes

content: First, tell us exactly what you want to do, as your post is not clear. For example, are you wanting to create a backup of the profile, or are you wanting to extract some messages? With more clarity, I believe we may be able to assist.

content:
I started writing a reply in this topic https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1453470, but became aware there are four support issues open, almost identical in nature. So chose this topic to reply in and I will close the other. I suggest you note this link to this topic and contain your replies to this topic only. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1453447

As you refer to syncing, I assume you have an IMAP account. Archiving in an IMAP Gmail account only works in relation to the gmail all mail folder being the target for the archive action.

Any movement of mail to local folder is done manually and the number involved each time should be limited to only a few hundred email at a time as the more email are selected to move at a time the greater the risk of data loss (emails) in the process.

@David, I am assuming this is letting you know he needed instructions.https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1453255

I think discussion on this topic https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1453277 should also be included here as it looks like it is all related to archiving mail from Gmail to a local store.

I have left the other two topics open, but can close them if you like.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: Your last sentence is what I wanted: your goal. The easiest way, in my opinion, is to create some folders in Local Folders, and periodically COPY messages there prior to deleting them. Then, delete (move to trash) the messages just copied. That would be my approach as it lets me stay in control. Understand, you need to do periodic backups because if your PC crashes, you lose those messages.
creator: davidsk

content:
Folderflags will set the value, but it will be reset to what it needs to be, either from the servers definition of the drafts folder, or your settings in account settings.

For an example, there should be no use case I can think of where an IMAP server would allow an inbox to be used as a drafts folder. Just going to make all the inbox mails have a button to edit them as drafts, even if it was successful. But the account setting would allow yo to do so I think. Have you checked them?

What exactly are you trying to do here?

content:
Do you have an exception in bit defender to prevent it scanning in the Thunderbird profile folder while the program is running?

One of the greatest points of failure in Thunderbird is not getting access to its own files when it seeks them because some lumbering dinosaur of an antivirus is scanning at its leisure. Removing the point of failure is all most folk require for a trouble free experience.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Matt,

No, I did not have that folder as an exception (a bit scary due to e-mail being a dodgy vector for malware and viruses to get right in) but I'll set that up and see how it goes for a day or two and let you know.

Note that Bitdefender did add an anti-spam filter to Thunderbird (I OK'd it) but it's currently disabled as I try to determine what's going on and may remove it as T'bird does a decent job on its own on dropping garbage into the junk folder.

Give me a day or two to test this suggestion and I'll let you know if this worked or not.

I should search for this but do you know off hand if T'bird has a log that shows what it's doing when "Assembling message....." is running and if it's catching some issue on its own?

Thanks!

content:

Looks like part of the issue might have been a POP server configuration mismatch somehow (settings on my end were not changed but maybe my e-mail provider had some change) and I re-created my POP account in Thunderbird and everything is working OK for the time being and I have not seen the "Assembling message" prompt anymore.

So I'll leave it as is for now and see how it goes. Due to the re-creation of the POP account at the same time I excluded Bitdefender per your suggestion, I can't say which is the "solution" to my problem so I'll not yet mark your reply as a solution. In a couple weeks I'll remove the exception and see if the issue returns. If so, I'll know you were correct and I'll mark it as a solution.

Thanks!

content:
Are you another of those with an American ISP that has recently required users to have an Outgoing server(SMTP) for each address they send mail from, instead of sharing the same one for multiple email addresses.

Go to outgoing server(SMTP) in your account settings and ensure you have an entry for each address you with to send mails from. Then go to the corresponding incoming account and make sure the correct outgoing server is selected for the account.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
So you need to change your authentication method from whatever you use now to oauth.

  1. Step one is make sure the server names is correct. Incoming needs to be outlook.office365.com outgoing in outgoing server (SMTP) needs to be smtp.office365.com
  2. If you needed to make a server name change, restart Thunderbird.
  3. Change the authentication method to OAuth.
  4. Complete the authentication flow of web pages for the initial authentication when Thunderbird attempts to get or send mail for the first time after the change.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
You are dealing with an IMAP account! Is the account settings in Synchronization and Storage even set to store messages in a local folder? IMAP does not necessarily have a local copy.

If you want to export email to a PDF, I suggest you use the import export tools addon to manage the email, not hacking around with system storage files.

https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/addon/importexporttools-ng/?src=ss

Once you have the addon installed it is as simple as right clicking the folder and following the menu.
creator: MattAuSupport
